But it looks like we have something similar in nova [0][1]?

[0] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/conf/cinder.py#L46
[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/volume/cinder.py#L208-L211

Yeah - I can't think of a good reason to set explicit endpoint URLs for a services.

I lightly dug through some other projects to see what they did and that's how I stumbled across the nova bits, but it doesn't sound like there isn't anything stopping from them refactoring that approach (outside of resources)?

I got your point,
but I think both swift_store_endpoint and service_type/endpoint_type are complementary.
I mean with swift_store_endpoint we can completely override end point using
puppet/ansible/terraform or alternatively add and select an entry in catalog.
From my use case, I manage glance servers but not keystone database which is handled by an another team. So in my context deal with this parameter to setup a local haproxy with my existing deployment tool is a bit more flexible.

I wouldn't doubt it, I think we've got lots of direct url legacy in a lot of projects. I'm not saying we shouldn't do this, but since it's proposed instead of landed, it seems like it's probably good to head in the preferred direction instead of adding more legacy, unless there is a good reason.

setup.cfg.message:
In the bug report, you say "There is a requirement to use _list_available_rest_versions()` which produces a list of supported versions which can then be used to see if a required version for a feature is actually supported."  Is that the reason for bumping the min to 1.17.0?  What I'm getting at is, does the code change in pure.py work for older versions of purestorage?  This is a pretty big jump in requirements for a backport.

(Just so I don't forget, purestorage is in upper-constraints for wallaby at 1.19.0 [0].  Not sure if that helps your case for a backport or not.)

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/src/branch/stable/wallaby/upper-constraints.txt#L294

The `_list_available_rest_versions` call works with all older versions of the SDK so there is no backwards incompatibility.

The reason we are hitting the bug was the SDK version from 1.16 provides a different response to the `get_rest_version` call. It appears the previous response format was a bug that has taken a long time to surface. 

TBH the 1.6.0 version is very old (2016) and should have been bumped many times, especially when newer features were added to the driver.

The SDK in question is never going to go beyond 1.19, so the upper constraints will never change now.

ansible/roles/monasca/handlers/main.yml.message:
For people upgrading, I think we need to delete the container to update the restart policy. If I apply this patch to a running deployment of Monasca, I see the thresh container constantly restarting after exiting 0 and finding a Storm topology. The restart policy remains as 'unless-stopped'. Apart from that it works well.

I was thinking that a simpler approach could be to submit the topology during bootstrap_service.yml. So spin up your one time container in there, on one node, and run your script to submit it if it's not already running (keep that check in the script). We could add some cleanup logic for the legacy monasca_thresh container and just remove it everywhere.

On upgrade, we could run the same bootstrap task, but pass in an ENV var to remove the topology  prior to deploying a more recent version. This env var could be optional - Monasca Thresh is rarely updated (unfortunately).

One other thing is that I see the logs from the topology get written out in the Storm directory. If you have time, please could you include those in the Fluentd config so they end up in Elastic?. If not, we can leave that for another patch, since the current logs aren't ingested by Fluentd anyway.

Makes sense to move this all to bootstrap (provided the storm is available) -- I'll still need to check for topology changes to trigger replacement of course.   Also, if there's an old non-bootstrap container out there (upgrade), removing it will need to trigger a bootstrap submission.  Fun 😊

I'll look into the log issue too, if it's not too involved.

Latest set uses the script which is submitted to Kolla to check/remove the topology.

I decided against the bootstrap idea: topology submissions need to handle changes, and aren't static initialization.  So now there's a replacement "monasca_thresh" container that submits any missing topology (and should replace any old "local" container on upgrade/restart), and also a one-shot+removed "reconfigure_monasca_thresh" container triggered by topology changes.  This allows deploys to work cleanly (container exists, and is in the expected "exited" state), and still handle any local/upgrade topology changes.  Host restarts should also work w/o problems.

I figured I'll leave the fluentd issue until later, as there might be an problem with logs creating logs, and I don't want to create a loop.
I suppose we could rename this now to 'submit monasca-thresh topology' or something similar?

Of course, another option would be to break monasca-thresh out of the monasca_services list and handle it on it's own.  That approach would allow it to be correctly handled as a "non-running" container, but would require that the user be warned that any custom configs for it under monasca_services:monasca-thresh would need to be moved on upgrade.

The name has to stay Restart as it's used in the check-containers loop as a template 😊

I'll update the Reconfigure to Resubmitting though.

cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message:
The size returned after rbd self._clone seems to be correct, the problem is that cinder forces to truncate the size of the volume after that. This happens because when using encryption cinder is not considering the size of the encryption header.

What we should do is calculate the new size and add it to the target volume instead of truncating it:

```
size difference = desired size - size of source volume
new size = current size + size difference 
```
good idea, i will try to fix this according to this.
I think we need more than 1M. In the case of LUKSv1 as far as I tested it needs at least 3M.

i tested it again in my environment. i needs at least 2M.
1: created an encryption rbd volume.
2: rbd export volumes/volume-xxxxxxxxx ./volume-xxxxxx
3: qemu-img info volume-xxxxxx
   ...
   payload_offset: 2068480     (this is 2020K, almost 2M)

However, no matter how big the encryption head, We simply get the allocation size of the volume, then use the above method to calculate the size of the extend.
There's an extra comma here
isn't this the same as volume.size at L#1058?

I think this provides the size in bytes, again the question is isn't this same as
volume.size *  units.Gi?
I checked this and it came out to be 1025 MB (maybe can vary depending on the encryption parameters) so yes different from what openstack assumes i.e. 1024

It isn't. I guess this should be transparent to Cinder but in case that the volume is encrypted, the vol.volume.size is 1026M instead of 1024. Because of that, volume.size is 1024 and vol.volume.size is 1026.

If we're creating a 1GB encrypted volume from the snapshot of 1GB encrypted volume, this will be 1 > 1 ? False which will not perform the resize but the issue while mounting still persists

https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1852168
shouldn't this be volume.size? else we might face problem while resizing if destination volume is not encrypted

As far as I see it, the idea of this fix is only force resize when the destination
volume size is bigger than the source volumes and calculate the new size based on the difference and not in round numbers.

i.e: In case of encrypted volume, the real size of the volume in the backend is 1026M but Cinder shows 1024. Currently the size after rbd self._clone seems to be correct, the problem is that cinder forces to truncate the size of the volume after that. This happens because when using encryption cinder is not considering the size of the encryption header.

What we should do is calculate the new size and add it to the target volume instead of truncating it:
size difference = desired size - size of source volume
new size = current size + size difference 

i.e:
desired size = 2048M (volume.size)
size of source volume = 1024M (snapshot.volume.size)
size difference = 1024M
current size = 1026M
new size =  2050M

The second scenario is when the volume isn't encrypted but the used would like to increase the size of the destination volume. Using new_size = None avoids let's cinder resize without problems.

What about the case when source and final volume will be 2 GB?
What will be the value of int(volume.size) and int(snapshot.volume.size), 2GB? Then will we enter this loop?
if this is always true then we don't need this if block and if it isn't true the new_size value is None and might cause problem on L#1066 while resizing
You're right, I should've seen the implementation before so setting this as None initially won't cause issue.

As far as I understand, this isn't always true. In case we'd like to create a bigger non-encrypted destination volume from that snapshot, we wouldn't calculate the new size. 

I'm not sure why this may cause problem? AFAIK if the size is None it will return size = int(volume.size) * units.Gi.[1]
[1]https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py#L1038

I'm not able to understand the calculation going on here.
we're taking the difference of original volume and volume created from snapshot and then adding that difference to the destination volume, can't we just resize it to the original volume size directly?
self._resize(volume, size=snapshot.volume.size)

This is a good concerns, as far as I see it, if the user want 2G = 2048M encrypted volume to use, cinder should return that. The amount of space of the encryption header isn't available space to use so cinder needs to add it to 2048M instead of truncate the volume.

Ignore my previous, comment but i still don't understand the calculation
destination size = destination volume size + difference of destination and original volume?
the destination size is already bigger and we're adding additional difference to it?
This is returning an absolute number of bytes and not a diff -- naming this "diff" is misleading.
i have change this function to def _calculate_new_size().

?: Why are we casting them to ints?  They are already fields.IntegerField

yes, we should use snapshot.volume_size.
-1: Same issue as L1058 and also, we could store size_diff before L1058 and use it in both places so we don't have to calculate it twice

1:Done, remove int().
2:we only calculate size_diff in line 1063, and this value is needed only when volume.size > snapshot.volume_size and volume.encryption_key_id, so i don't think it need to move before L1058.
As Gorka's commented before I think we could add a new line before L1058 with something like snap_volume_size = snapshot.volume_size. In this way, we don't have to calculate it twice.

whitebox_tempest_plugin/api/compute/test.message:
I think a more Pythonic way of doing this would be:

  # NOTE(jparker) Nova change I11fb5d3ada7f27b39c183157ea73c8b72b4e672e
  # changed the interface type from 'bridge' to 'ethernet'. Try the latter first,
  # then fall back on the former.
  driver = domain.find(
      "devices/interface[@type='ethernet']/driver[@name='vhost']"
  ) or domain.find(
      "devices/interface[@type='bridge']/driver[@name='vhost']"
  )

I like this approach more, but python does not treat the result of the first method as 'True' if it is not None, e.g.:

>>> if domain.find("devices/interface[@type='ethernet']/driver[@name='vhost']"):
...     print('Ethernet interface found')
... 
>>> driver = domain.find("devices/interface[@type='ethernet']/driver[@name='vhost']")
>>> driver.attrib['rx_queue_size']
'1024'

So trying that results in a None return 
>>> driver = domain.find("devices/interface[@type='ethernet']/driver[@name='vhost']") or domain.find("devices/interface[@type='bridge']/driver[@name='vhost']")
>>> driver is None
True

To keep it close to this I could try something like:
>>> ethernet_interface = domain.find("devices/interface[@type='ethernet']/driver[@name='vhost']")
>>> driver = ethernet_interface if ethernet_interface is not None else domain.find("devices/interface[@type='bridge']/driver[@name='vhost']")
>>> driver.attrib['rx_queue_size']
'1024'

Wdyt?

Ah, fun: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.9/Lib/xml/etree/ElementTree.py#L214-L220

The way to work around this while remaining Pythonic would be:

  driver = tree.find("interface[@type='ethernet']/driver[@name='vhost']")
  driver = (driver if driver is not None
            else tree.find("interface[@type='bridge']/driver[@name='vhost']"))

@Kevin, the way this works is the key you add is specific to a particular zuul server that you are intending to use it with

Sagi has encrypted the password using the key of the zuul server and this is what we are storing here. Then only the zuul server whos key you used during the encryption will be able to decrypt and see/use the plain pass.

(https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/tools/encrypt_secret.py
https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/3.10.1/user/encryption.html)

No, secrets should be defined in project they are used in. It's not a bad form, although not all yaml parsers can understand it. It works here: https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-collections-openstack/src/branch/master/.zuul.yaml#L357
Or here: https://github.com/rdo-infra/review.rdoproject.org-config/blob/master/zuul.d/secrets.yaml
it all seems like a terrible means for storing information like this; that said, if this is how it works, so be it.

api-ref/source/v2/qos.inc.message:
A little reorganisation of the sections like below would probably make sense:

QoS DSCP marking rules
QoS bandwidth limit rules
QoS packet rate limit rules
QoS minimum bandwidth rules
QoS minimum packet rate rules
I'd suggest doing that in a separate patch, after we merge this change.
And we cannot delete a rule until there are ports referring to it, right?
We cannot delete a policy if there's a port referring to it. However, we should be able to delete individual rules.
It applies to other rule types as well, so I think we can address this issue in the same patch that is going to reorganize structure of this file.
Thanks. I wanted to mean that this information could be useful here in the reference.
The same reorganisation of sections as above would also help to find the rules.
Based on review comments from https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/803045, QoS rule alias is not going to be included in this extension. Thus, this section is going to be removed.

neutron_lib/api/definitions/qos_pps_mini.message: I think we should keep this as True to have a consistency across all qos rule types. If needed, we can block this update in the server.

And this is something I don't support: all qos rules should have the same API. If the spec is saying this, I don't support the spec neither.

This is a mistake to support rules with different APIs. Direction should be included here and rejected, if needed, in the server.
The spec allowed only min_kpps to be updated with PUT request. Of course, we can change that. Let's see what others have to say on this matter.

I think I found the relevant discussion in the spec review:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/785236/7/specs/xena/qos-minimum-guaranteed-packet-rate.rst#187

So not allowing PUT on direction is aligned with spec review, so I vote on this

I haven't participated in the spec review, so I don't know for sure what was the reason behind it. Perhaps, it had something to do with the fact that we have to support 'any' direction for PPS? Direction-oriented and directionless QoS minimum PPS rules are mutually exclusive. Even if that was the reason, I suppose we can still allow PUT request. We just have to ensure that we won't end up mixing direction-oriented and directionless PPS rules.

Yeah, good question, we allow put now on direction for other rule types, not sure why in the spec it was voted to not allow put on it:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/branch/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/qos.py#L162
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/branch/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/qos_pps_rule.py#L61

Hmm, good catch Rodolfo. Maybe we should fix it quickly now to allow it here and raise exception in the service plugin code if e.g. rule is already used by any port. Like Rodolfo proposed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/785236/7/specs/xena/qos-minimum-guaranteed-packet-rate.rst#187
We have this and next week to merge it and release new neutron-lib version before final release for Xena. So we should be able to do it.
Is this intentional or should it be 'any'?
Intentional. In my opinion there's no good default value for this parameter. 'Any' direction doesn't make sense in case of hardware-offloaded OVS deployment.
No. This API extension is not going to introduce QoS rule alias. Please see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/803045/2/neutron/extensions/qos_pps_minimum_rule.py#57 for more details.

rally/rally-plugins/dynamic-workloads/tr.message: As jump host is created before the subports, move this (i.e "ip r" command) to line number 204
I see that we have a variable image_name, flavor_name in browbeat-config.yaml, why can't you use it?

image_name and flavor_name in browbeat-config.yaml get converted to image id and flavor id because of validation and type conversion in dynamic_workload.py. So I have to check for image name and flavor name using the ids here.

The image and flavor for VM scenarios will mostly be cirros,m1.xtiny. I agree with your point that we should minimise calls to glance APIs in dynamic workloads. I will reuse image_name and flavor_name over here.

Sorry, my reply doesn't exactly explain why I am retrieving the ids here. image_name and flavor_name in browbeat-config.yaml are for the vm scenarios. For the jump host here, we are sure that we want to use only 'cirros' and 'm1.xtiny', so we do not take any parameters for these. image_name and flavor_name can be changed in browbeat-config.yaml, but we want jump host image and flavor to be constant. That is why I am not using them here.

Jump host is used in most of the scenarios and all the time it requires only m1.xtiny and cirros. So we can think about having 
_create_jumphost(network, ext_net_id) in utils and take jumphost_image and jumphost_flavor from user.
But let's do it later.
Which image and flavor are you planning to use for VM scenarios?

code can be optimized as 
        jump_host, jump_fip = self._boot_server_with_fip(jump_host_image,
            jump_host_flavor,
            True,
            ext_net_name,
            key_name=self.keypair["name"],
            **kwargs,
        )
Ack
you already have the images in line 121
The self.clients("glance").images.list() function can only be iterated once per function call. It returns an empty list when it is reused. That is why I am using it again.

I also have same doubt as Asma. Is "images" in line 121  a list or pointer. If it is a pointer to "list" function, then line 122 is retrieving the list by calling this function. But I think images in line 121 is a list and not a pointer.
by default in browbeat-config.yaml we have user variable set to cirros user, check if it can be re-used

Agree with Asma. We can't hard code or check user or image in the code. Though it adds many variables in the config, we should go by variables. Browbeat installation might be creating user and images, but user might have deleted them or re created with different names. Let https://review.opendev.org/c/x/browbeat/+/803732/2/rally/rally-plugins/dynamic-workloads/dynamic_workload.yml have defaults and you can only add mandatory fields in browbeat-config.yaml
I can create a parameter called trunk_vm_user in browbeat-config.yaml and use that here, to minimise glance API calls.

We are using centos7 image mostly for the trunk subport simulation, as cirros doesn't work that well. The reason why I didn't add another variable for trunk VM user is because the jump host is cirros here and the trunk VM is centos7 most of the time. So instead of adding too many variables in browbeat-config.yaml, I am checking for user in the code.
same here
Ack
get jumphost on the trunk network and use that for connection test
